home.title: Learn JavaScript
home.subtitle: The Programming Language of the Web

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: JavaScript is easy to learn.
This tutorial covers everything from basic JavaScript up to the latest 2025 version.
Start learning JavaScript now.

sections.heading: Examples in Each Chapter
paragraphs: With our Try it Yourself editor, you can edit the source code and view the result.

example.title: My First JavaScript
example.description: Click me to display Date and Time

sections.heading: Use the Menu
paragraphs: We recommend reading this tutorial in the sequence listed in the menu.
On large screens, the menu appears on the left.
On small screens, open the menu using the ☰ icon.

sections.heading: Learn by Examples
paragraphs: Examples are better than 1000 words.
Examples are often easier to understand than text explanations.
This tutorial includes Try it Yourself examples for every concept.
sections.note: Trying all examples will help you learn JavaScript faster.

sections.heading: Why Study JavaScript?
paragraphs: JavaScript is one of the three core web technologies:
HTML defines content.
CSS controls layout.
JavaScript controls behavior.

sections.heading: Learning Speed
paragraphs: You control the learning speed.
If something feels difficult, take a break and review the examples.
The best way to learn programming is practice.

sections.heading: Commonly Asked Questions
answers: JavaScript runs directly in your browser.

sections.heading: JavaScript Exercises
paragraphs: Many chapters include exercises to test your knowledge.

exercise.question: What is the correct syntax for assigning a value to a variable?

sections.heading: JavaScript Quiz
paragraphs: Test your JavaScript skills with quizzes.

sections.heading: Track Your Progress
paragraphs: Create an account to track tutorials, exercises, and quizzes.
Maintain daily streaks and compete on leaderboards.
Create a personal website and customize your avatar.

sections.heading: JavaScript References
paragraphs: Complete JavaScript references are maintained and regularly updated.
Includes properties, methods, and events.

sections.heading: Get Certified
paragraphs: Complete the JavaScript course to earn certification.

footer.copyright: Copyright 1999-2026 by Refsnes Data. All Rights Reserved.

sections.heading: Syntax Rules
sections.description: Syntax are the rules how programs must be constructed.
code: // I am a Comment. I do Nothing

sections.heading: JavaScript Values
sections.description: The JavaScript syntax defines two types of values:

sections.heading: JavaScript Literals
rules: Numbers are written with or without decimals
Strings are written within double or single quotes

sections.heading: JavaScript Keywords
sections.description: JavaScript keywords are used to defines actions to be performed.
note: LET or Let is not interpreted as let

sections.heading: JavaScript Variables
sections.description: Variables are containers for storing data values.
rules: Variables must be identified with unique names

sections.heading: JavaScript Identifiers
sections.description: An identifier is the name you give to a variable.
rules: Must start with a letter, _ or $
Can contain digits after the first character
Cannot be a reserved keyword
Are case-sensitive

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is a correct syntax for assigning a value to a variable?

footer.note: W3Schools is optimized for learning and training.

sections.heading: Variables = Data Containers
paragraphs: JavaScript variables are containers for data.
Variables are labels for data values.
Variables are containers for storing data.

sections.heading: Ways to Declare Variables
paragraphs: JavaScript variables can be declared in four ways.

sections.heading: Example Using let
Example Using const
JavaScript Identifiers
paragraphs: Variables are identified with unique names called identifiers.
Identifiers can be short or descriptive.
rules: Names can contain letters, digits, underscores, and dollar signs
Names must begin with a letter, $ sign, or underscore
Names are case sensitive
Reserved words cannot be used

sections.heading: JavaScript Underscore (_)
paragraphs: JavaScript treats underscore as a letter.

sections.heading: JavaScript Dollar Sign ($)
paragraphs: JavaScript treats dollar sign as a letter.
Often used as an alias in JavaScript libraries.

sections.heading: Declaring Variables
paragraphs: Creating a variable is called declaring a variable.
Use let or const keywords.

sections.heading: Mixed Example
Using var (Not Recommended)
paragraphs: var was used before 2015.
let and const were introduced in 2015.

sections.heading: When to Use let, const, or var
points: Use const if value should not change
Use const for arrays and objects
Use let if const cannot be used

sections.heading: JavaScript Data Types
paragraphs: JavaScript variables can hold 8 data types.
Strings are written inside quotes.
Numbers are written without quotes.

sections.heading: Assignment Operator
paragraphs: The = operator assigns values.
It is different from == which compares values.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What is NOT a correct syntax for declaring variables?

sections.heading: Operators for Computation
paragraphs: Operators are for Mathematical and Logical Computations.

sections.heading: JavaScript Assignment
paragraphs: The Assignment Operator (=) assigns a value to a variable.
examples:
// Assign the value 5 to x
let x = 5;

// Assign the value 2 to y
let y = 2;

// Assign the value x + y to z
let z = x + y;

sections.heading: JavaScript Addition
paragraphs: The Addition Operator (+) adds numbers.

sections.heading: JavaScript Multiplication
paragraphs: The Multiplication Operator (*) multiplies numbers.

sections.heading: JavaScript Arithmetic Operators
paragraphs: Arithmetic Operators are used to perform arithmetic on numbers.

sections.heading: JavaScript String Addition
paragraphs: The + operator can concatenate strings.

sections.heading: String Addition Assignment
paragraphs: The += operator can also concatenate strings.
sections.example:
let text1 = "What a very ";
text1 += "nice day";

sections.heading: Adding Strings and Numbers
paragraphs: Adding numbers results in numbers.
Adding a number and a string results in a string.

sections.heading: JavaScript Assignment Operators
paragraphs: Assignment operators assign values to JavaScript variables.

sections.heading: JavaScript Comparison Operators
paragraphs: Comparison operators compare two values.
They always return true or false.

sections.heading: Comparison on Strings
paragraphs: Strings are compared alphabetically.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What will be the result of z?

sections.heading: Conditional Statements
paragraphs: Conditional Statements allow us to perform different actions for different conditions.
Conditional statements run different code depending on true or false conditions.

sections.heading: When to Use Conditionals
lists: Use if to specify a code block to be executed, if a specified condition is true
Use else to specify a code block to be executed, if the same condition is false
Use else if to specify a new condition to test, if the first condition is false
Use switch to specify many alternative code blocks to be executed
Use (? :) (ternary) as a shorthand for if...else

sections.heading: The if Statement
paragraphs: Use if to specify a code block to be executed, if a specified condition is true.

sections.heading: The else Statement
paragraphs: Use else to specify a code block to be executed, if the same condition is false.

sections.heading: The else if Statement
paragraphs: Use else if to specify a new condition to test, if the first condition is false.

sections.heading: The switch Statement
paragraphs: Use switch to specify many alternative code blocks to be executed.

sections.heading: Ternary Operator (? :)
paragraphs: Use (? :) (ternary) as a shorthand for if...else.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Loops can execute a block of code a number of times.
Loops are handy if you want to run the same code over and over again, each time with a different value.

sections.heading: Loops and Arrays
paragraphs: Often loops are used when working with arrays.

sections.heading: The For Loop
paragraphs: The for statement creates a loop with three optional expressions.
expressions: expr1 is executed one time before the execution of the code block.
expr2 defines the condition for executing the code block.
expr3 is executed every time the code block has been executed.
explanation: expr1 sets a variable before the loop starts (let i = 0).
expr2 defines the condition for the loop to run (i must be less than 5).
expr3 increases a value (i++) each time the code block has been executed.

sections.heading: Loop Scope
notes: In the first example, the variable is declared outside the loop.
In the second example, the variable is declared inside the loop.
Variables declared with let or const inside a loop are only visible within the loop.

sections.heading: The While Loop
paragraphs: The while loop loops through a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.
sections.note: If you forget to increase the variable used in the condition, the loop will never end and may crash your browser.

sections.heading: The Do While Loop
paragraphs: The do while loop is a variant of the while loop.
The do while loop executes the code block once before checking the condition.
notes: The do while loop runs at least once, even if the condition is false.
Always increase the variable used in the condition to avoid infinite loops.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Strings are for storing text.
Strings are written with quotes.

sections.heading: Using Quotes
paragraphs: A JavaScript string is zero or more characters written inside quotes.
notes: You can use single or double quotes.
Strings created with single or double quotes work the same.
There is no difference between the two.

sections.heading: Quotes Inside Quotes
paragraphs: You can use quotes inside a string as long as they don't match the quotes surrounding the string.

sections.heading: Template Strings
paragraphs: Template strings were introduced in ES6 (JavaScript 2016).
Templates are strings enclosed in backticks.
Template strings allow both single and double quotes inside a string.

sections.heading: String Length
paragraphs: To find the length of a string, use the built-in length property.

sections.heading: Escape Characters
paragraphs: JavaScript uses escape characters to handle special characters inside strings.
sections.invalid_example: let text = "We are the so-called "Vikings" from the north.";
examples: let text = "We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north.";
let text = "The character \\ is called backslash.";
sections.note: These escape characters were originally designed for typewriters and do not have meaning in HTML.

sections.heading: Breaking Long Lines
paragraphs: For readability, programmers often like to avoid long code lines.

sections.heading: Multiline Template Strings
paragraphs: Template strings allow multiline strings.
sections.example:
let text = `The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy dog`;

sections.heading: JavaScript Strings as Objects
paragraphs: Normally, JavaScript strings are primitive values.
Strings can also be defined as objects using the new keyword.
Do not create String objects.
warnings: The new keyword complicates code and slows execution.
String objects can produce unexpected results.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: Which one of the following is not a legal JavaScript String?

sections.heading: Number Types
paragraphs: JavaScript has only one type of number.
Numbers can be written with or without decimals.

examples.code:
let x = 3.14; // A number with decimals
let y = 3; // A number without decimals

sections.heading: JavaScript Numbers are Always 64-bit Floating Point
paragraphs: JavaScript does not define different types of numbers like integers or floats.
All numbers are stored as double precision floating point numbers following the IEEE 754 standard.

sections.heading: Integer Precision
paragraphs: Integers are accurate up to 15 digits.
The maximum number of decimals is 17.

sections.heading: Floating Precision
paragraphs: Floating point arithmetic is not always 100% accurate.

sections.heading: Adding Numbers and Strings
sections.warning: The + operator is used for both addition and concatenation.

sections.heading: Numeric Strings
paragraphs: JavaScript converts numeric strings to numbers in arithmetic operations.
The + operator concatenates strings.

sections.heading: NaN (Not a Number)
paragraphs: NaN indicates a value that is not a legal number.
NaN is of type number.

sections.heading: Infinity
paragraphs: Infinity is returned when a number exceeds the largest possible value.
Division by zero generates Infinity.

sections.heading: Hexadecimal Numbers
paragraphs: Hexadecimal numbers start with 0x.
Avoid leading zeros.

sections.heading: JavaScript Numbers as Objects
paragraphs: Numbers are normally primitive values.
Avoid using Number objects created with new.

examples.code:
let x = 123;
let y = new Number(123);

exercise.question: What will be the result of x + y?

overview.title: Functions Learning Path
overview.description: Learn functions in the right order:

beginner.title: Calling (Invoking) Functions
beginner.description: How to run a function and how to use it.

beginner.title: Parameters and Arguments
beginner.description: How to send values into a function.

beginner.title: Function Return Values
beginner.description: How a function sends a value back.

intermediate.title: Function Expressions
intermediate.description: A function expression is stored in a variable.

intermediate.title: Arrow Functions
intermediate.description: A shorter function syntax, with some important differences.

intermediate.title: IIFE (Advanced)
intermediate.description: Functions that run immediately (mostly historical, still useful sometimes).

intermediate.title: Function Quiz
intermediate.description: Test your knowledge of JavaScript functions.

steps.title: The this Keyword
description: How this works (especially inside objects).
How this is decided by how it is called.

steps.title: call(): Set this and pass arguments
steps.description: Call a function with a chosen this value.

steps.title: apply(): Like call(), but arguments as an array
steps.description: Use apply() when you already have an array of values.

steps.title: bind(): Create a new function with fixed this
steps.description: Use bind() when you need a function to run later with the same this.

steps.title: Closures: Functions Remember Their Scope
steps.description: Learn how functions can remember variables after the outer function finishes.

steps.title: Function References and Callbacks
steps.description: Pass functions as values and avoid common callback mistakes.

description: An object is a variable that can hold many variables.
Objects are collections of key-value pairs where each key is a property name.
Objects can describe real-world entities like cars, houses, people, or animals.

object_example.title: Car Object
notes: Different objects can have the same properties with different values.
Objects can share methods but execute them at different times.

object_creation.title: Creating JavaScript Objects
notes: Use const to declare objects.
const prevents reassignment but allows property modification.

using_new_keyword.title: Using the new Keyword
using_new_keyword.example: const person = new Object({ firstName: "John", lastName: "Doe", age: 50, eyeColor: "blue" });
using_new_keyword.recommendation: Object literals are preferred for readability, simplicity, and performance.

object_methods.title: JavaScript Object Methods
object_methods.description: Object methods are functions stored as property values.
object_methods.this_keyword: The keyword this refers to the current object.

displaying_objects.title: Displaying JavaScript Objects
notes: Displaying an object directly outputs [object Object].
Object properties should be accessed individually.

constructor_functions.title: Object Constructor Functions
constructor_functions.description: Constructor functions allow creation of multiple objects of the same type.
constructor_functions.note: Constructor function names should start with an uppercase letter.

key_points: Methods are functions stored as properties.
Almost everything in JavaScript is an object.

primitives_vs_objects.note: All JavaScript values except primitives are objects.

exercise.question: How many properties does the following object have?

description: Scope determines the accessibility (visibility) of variables.
JavaScript variables have three types of scope: Global, Function, and Block.
Variables declared outside any block or function have Global Scope.
Global variables can be accessed from anywhere in the program.
notes: All scripts and functions on the same page can access global variables.

description: Variables defined inside a function are only accessible within that function.
They have Function Scope and are also called local variables.
notes: Local variables are created when the function starts and deleted when it finishes.
Arguments (parameters) act as local variables inside functions.

description: Introduced in ES6 with let and const keywords.
Variables declared inside a block ({ }) are only accessible within that block.
examples: { let x = 2; } // x cannot be used here
{ var y = 2; } // y CAN be used here (not recommended)
notes: Block scope helps prevent unintended variable overwrites.

description: Assigning a value to an undeclared variable makes it global (not recommended).
Strict Mode prevents undeclared variables from becoming global.
Global scope in HTML corresponds to the window object.
Variables declared with var belong to window, but let/const do not.
examples: let carName = 'Volvo'; // window.carName does NOT exist

notes: Do not create global variables unless intended.
Global variables can be overwritten by other scripts or window functions.

description: Variable lifetime starts when declared.
Function (local) variables are deleted when function ends.
Global variables in browsers are deleted when the browser/tab is closed.
JavaScript Date Objects let us work with dates and times.
By default, JavaScript will use the browser's time zone and display a date as a full text string.
Date objects are created with the new Date() constructor.
There are 9 ways to create a new date object.
examples: new Date(year, month, day, hours, minutes)
new Date(year, month, day, hours, minutes, seconds)
new Date(year, month, day, hours, minutes, seconds, ms)

description: Date objects are static. They do not automatically update as time passes.
Months are zero-indexed: January = 0, December = 11.
Specifying values higher than valid ranges results in overflow to the next unit (month/year).
One and two digit years are interpreted as 19xx.

specific_date_numbers: const d = new Date(2018, 15, 24, 10, 33, 30); // overflow example
milliseconds: const d = new Date(100000000000); // 100 billion ms after Jan 1, 1970
const d = new Date(-100000000000); // 100 billion ms before Jan 1, 1970

description: Date methods allow you to get and set the year, month, day, hour, minute, second, and millisecond of date objects.
You can use local time or UTC (universal) time.
displaying_dates: toString(): Converts date to string including time zone.
toDateString(): Converts date to a more readable format.
toUTCString(): Converts date to UTC standard.
toISOString(): Converts date to ISO standard.

exercise.question: What date is created with the following code: const d = new Date(2024, 10, 18); ?

description: An Array is an object type designed for storing data collections.
Elements are ordered and zero-indexed.
Arrays are dynamic in size and can hold heterogeneous elements (numbers, strings, objects, or even other arrays).
Arrays let you store many values under a single name and access them using an index.
This makes it easy to loop through lists and manage large collections.

array_literal.description: The easiest way to create an array is using an array literal.

using_new_keyword.note: Using 'new Array()' is equivalent, but array literal syntax is recommended for simplicity and speed.

accessing_and_modifying_elements.access:
const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];
let car = cars[0]; // Access first element

array_to_string.description: The toString() method converts an array to a comma-separated string.
array_to_string.example:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = fruits.toString(); // Result: Banana,Orange,Apple,Mango

description: Arrays are special types of objects. typeof returns 'object'.
Arrays use numbers for indexing elements, while objects use named keys.
Arrays can contain objects, functions, or other arrays as elements.
examples: const personArray = ["John", "Doe", 46]; // Array element access: personArray[0] returns 'John'
const personObject = {firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe", age:46}; // Object property access: personObject.firstName returns 'John'

description: JavaScript arrays have built-in properties and methods.
The most commonly used are 'length' and 'sort()'.
A JavaScript Set is a collection of unique values.
Each value can occur only once in a Set.
The values can be of any type: primitives or objects.

methods.method: Pass an array to new Set()
methods.example:
// Create a Set
const letters = new Set(["a","b","c"]);

methods.method: Create an empty set and add values with add()
Create variables and add them to a Set

add_method.description: The add() method adds a new value to the Set. Duplicate values are ignored.

listing_elements.description: You can list all Set elements using a for..of loop.

description: Sets are special types of objects.
typeof returns 'object'.
instanceof Set returns true.
Set is an ES6 feature and fully supported in all modern browsers since 2017.
You should use Sets when you need to store unique values and prevent duplicates.
A JavaScript Map is an object that can store collections of key-value pairs, similar to a dictionary in other languages.
Map keys can be of any data type.
Maps remember the original insertion order of keys.
Maps are optimized for frequent additions and removals of key-value pairs.

map_characteristics.key_types: Map keys can be any type (strings, numbers, objects, etc).
map_characteristics.insertion_order: The Map remembers the original insertion order of the keys.
map_characteristics.size: The number of items in a Map is retrieved using the size property.
map_characteristics.performance: Maps are optimized for frequent additions and removals of key-value pairs.
map_characteristics.iteration: Maps are iterable, allowing for for...of loops or methods like forEach().

methods.method: Create an empty Map and add elements with set()
Pass an existing array to the Map constructor

adding_and_changing_values.description: You can add or change elements using the set() method.
examples: fruits.set("mangos", 100); // Adds a new key-value pair
fruits.set("apples", 200); // Changes the value of an existing key

getting_values.description: Use the get() method to retrieve the value of a key.

maps_are_objects.description: Maps are objects. You can check using typeof and instanceof.

comparison.object: Do not have a size property
Keys must be Strings or Symbols

description: Map is an ES6 feature and fully supported in all modern browsers since 2017.
Use Maps when you need key-value collections that are iterable and preserve insertion order.

javascript-math.title: JavaScript Math Object

description: The JavaScript Math object allows you to perform mathematical tasks.
The Math object is static: all methods and properties can be used without creating a Math object first.

properties.description: JavaScript provides 8 mathematical constants that can be accessed as Math properties.

rounding.description: 4 common methods to round a number to an integer.
rounding.Math.round: Returns x rounded to the nearest integer
rounding.Math.ceil: Returns x rounded up to the nearest integer
rounding.Math.floor: Returns x rounded down to the nearest integer
rounding.Math.trunc: Returns the integer part of x (ES6)

sign.description: Returns if x is negative, zero, or positive
sign.note: Math.trunc() and Math.sign() were added in ES6

power_and_root.Math.pow: Returns x to the power of y, e.g., Math.pow(8,2)
power_and_root.Math.sqrt: Returns the square root of x, e.g., Math.sqrt(64)
power_and_root.Math.abs: Returns the absolute value of x, e.g., Math.abs(-4.7)

trigonometry.Math.sin: Returns sine of angle x in radians, e.g., Math.sin(90 * Math.PI / 180) = 1
trigonometry.Math.cos: Returns cosine of angle x in radians, e.g., Math.cos(0 * Math.PI / 180) = 1
trigonometry.note: Convert degrees to radians using: radians = degrees * PI / 180

min_max_random.Math.min: Returns lowest value in arguments, e.g., Math.min(0,150,30,-8,-200)
min_max_random.Math.max: Returns highest value in arguments, e.g., Math.max(0,150,30,-8,-200)
min_max_random.Math.random: Returns a random number between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive)

logarithms.Math.log: Returns natural logarithm of x, e.g., Math.log(2)
logarithms.Math.log2: Returns base 2 logarithm of x, e.g., Math.log2(8)
logarithms.Math.log10: Returns base 10 logarithm of x, e.g., Math.log10(1000)

exercise.question: What is a correct syntax for rounding down a number to its nearest integer?

notes: All Math methods are static.
Math.trunc() and Math.sign() are part of ES6.

description: A Regular Expression is a sequence of characters that forms a search pattern.
Regex is a common shorthand for a regular expression.
JavaScript RegExp is an object for handling Regular Expressions.
RegExp are used for text searching, replacing, and validation.
introduction.example: let text = 'Visit W3Schools'; let n = text.search(/w3schools/i);

string_methods.search: Returns the index of the first match

alternation.description: An alternation uses | to match any of the alternatives.

flags.g: Performs a global match (find all occurrences)

quantifiers.x*: Matches zero or more occurrences of x
quantifiers.x?: Matches zero or one occurrences of x
quantifiers.x{n}: Matches exactly n occurrences of x
quantifiers.example: let result = text.match(/10?/g); // matches '1' followed by 0 zero or one times

assertions.^: Matches the beginning of a string
assertions.$: Matches the end of a string

character_classes.[abc]: Matches any character a, b, or c
character_classes.[a-z]: Matches all characters from a to z

exercise.question: What does the i modifier represent in Regular Expressions?

introduction.description: A JavaScript variable can hold 8 types of data: 7 primitive types and 1 object type. The object type can hold many different objects.

types.description: A number representing a mathematical value
A number representing a large integer
A text of characters enclosed in quotes
A data type representing true or false
types.example: let x = true; let y = false;

types.description: A primitive variable with no assigned value
A primitive value representing object absence
types.example: let x = null; let y = null;
const x = Symbol(); const y = Symbol();

types.description: A collection of key-value pairs of data

concept.description: Data types are important to safely operate on variables. JavaScript treats operations depending on types, e.g., adding a number and string concatenates them as strings.

dynamic-types.description: JavaScript has dynamic types; a variable can hold different types at different times.

strings.description: Strings are series of characters, enclosed in single or double quotes.

numbers.description: All JavaScript numbers are stored as 64-bit floating-point decimals.

exponentialNotation.description: Extra large or small numbers can be written using exponential notation.

numbers.note: JavaScript numbers are always 64-bit floating point (double).

bigint.description: BigInt can store integer values too large for normal Number.

introduction.description: When executing JavaScript code, different errors can occur due to coding mistakes, invalid input, or unforeseen issues. Common error types include Reference, Type, Range, URI, Syntax, and Eval errors.

error-types.description: Occurs if you reference a variable that does not exist.

examples.code:
let x = 5;
try { x = y + 1; } catch(err) { let text = err.name; }

error-types.description: Occurs when a value is of the wrong type or an operation is invalid for that type.
Occurs when a value is out of its valid range.

examples.error: toPrecision() argument must be between 1 and 100

error-types.description: Occurs if illegal characters are used in URI functions.
Occurs when code violates JavaScript grammar rules. Syntax errors happen before runtime and are not catchable by try...catch.
error-types.note: The JavaScript engine throws a SyntaxError before running the script. try...catch cannot catch syntax errors.

error-types.description: Indicates an error in the eval() function. Modern JavaScript does not throw EvalError; use SyntaxError instead.

handling-errors.description: The try statement defines a block of code to test for errors. The catch statement defines a block of code to handle errors if they occur.
handling-errors.syntax: try { /* code to try */ } catch(err) { /* code to handle errors */ }

exercise.question: Only one of the following words is a legal JavaScript statement, which one?

introduction.description: Always use consistent coding conventions for all your JavaScript projects to improve readability and maintainability.

components: Naming and declaration rules for variables and functions
Rules for white space, indentation, and comments

variables.naming: Use camelCase for variable and function names. All names start with a letter.

operators.guideline: Always put spaces around operators (=, +, -, *, /) and after commas
operators.example:
let x = y + z;
const myArray = ["Volvo", "Saab", "Fiat"];

indentation.guideline: Use 2 spaces for indentation. Do not use tabs.

rules: Put the opening bracket at the end of the first line with one space before it
Closing bracket on a new line without leading spaces
Do not end a complex statement with a semicolon
Opening bracket on same line as object name
Use colon plus one space between property and value
Quotes around string values, not numeric values
No comma after the last property
Closing bracket on new line
End object definition with a semicolon

line-length.guideline: Avoid lines longer than 80 characters. Break lines after operators or commas.

loading-scripts.guideline: Use simple syntax for external scripts. type attribute is not necessary.

html-elements.guideline: Use consistent naming between HTML IDs and JavaScript references.

file-extensions.guideline: Use lower case file names for consistency and server compatibility

performance.note: Coding conventions improve readability. Indentation and spaces have little effect on performance. Minify production scripts for efficiency.

introduction.description: JavaScript statements start with a statement identifier to indicate the action to be performed. Statement identifiers are reserved words and cannot be used as variable names or for other purposes.

statements.description: Creates a block of statements
Creates an AsyncFunction object
Creates an AsyncGeneratorFunction object
Declares local variables that are asynchronously disposed
Exits a switch or a loop
Declares a class
Declares a variable with a constant value
Breaks one iteration (in the loop) if a specified condition occurs, and continues with the next iteration in the loop
Stops the execution of JavaScript, and calls (if available) the debugging function
Executes a block of statements and repeats the block while a condition is true
Loops through a block of code a number of times
Loops through the properties of an object
Loops through the values of an iterable object
Loops over async iterable objects
Declares a function
Creates a GeneratorFunction object
Marks a block of statements to be executed depending on a condition
Defines a read-only import of a module
Defines how a module should be loaded
Declares a variable
Stops the execution of a function and returns a value
Marks a block of statements to be executed depending on different cases
Throws (generates) an error
Marks the block of statements to be executed when an error occurs in a try block, and implements error handling
Declares local variables that are synchronously disposed
Declares a variable
Marks a block of statements to be executed while a condition is true
